cards.name: Acidic Slime
cards.text:
Deathtouch (Any amount of damage this deals to a creature is enough to destroy it.)
When Acidic Slime enters the battlefield, destroy target artifact, enchantment, or land.
cards.originalText:
Deathtouch (Any amount of damage this deals to a creature is enough to destroy it.)
When Acidic Slime enters the battlefield, destroy target artifact, enchantment, or land.

cards.name: Aeon Chronicler
cards.text:
Aeon Chronicler's power and toughness are each equal to the number of cards in your hand.
Suspend X—{X}{3}{U}. X can't be 0.  (Rather than cast this card from your hand, you may pay {X}{3}{U} and exile it with X time counters on it. At the beginning of your upkeep, remove a time counter. When the last is removed, cast it without paying its mana cost. It has haste.)
Whenever a time counter is removed from Aeon Chronicler while it's exiled, draw a card.
cards.originalText:
Aeon Chronicler's power and toughness are each equal to the number of cards in your hand.
Suspend X—{X}{3}{U}. X can't be 0.
Whenever a time counter is removed from Aeon Chronicler while it's exiled, draw a card.

rulings.text: Both instances of X in the suspend ability are the same. You determine the value of X as you suspend the card from your hand. The value you choose must be at least 1.

If this is suspended, then when the last time counter is removed from it, both its triggered ability and the "play this card" part of the suspend ability will trigger. They can be put on the stack in either order.

You can exile a card in your hand using suspend any time you could cast that card. Consider its card type, any effect that affects when you could cast it (such as flash) and any other effects that could stop you from casting it (such as Meddling Mage's effect) to determine if and when you can do this. Whether or not you could actually complete all steps in casting the card is irrelevant. For example, you can exile a card with suspend that has no mana cost or requires a target even if no legal targets are available at that time.
Exiling a card with suspend isn't casting that card. This action doesn't use the stack and can't be responded to.
If the spell requires any targets, those targets are chosen when the spell is finally cast, not when it's exiled.
If the first triggered ability of suspend (the one that removes time counters) is countered, no time counter is removed. The ability will trigger again during the card's owner's next upkeep.
When the last time counter is removed, the second triggered ability of suspend will trigger. It doesn't matter why the last time counter was removed or what effect removed it.
If the second triggered ability of suspend (the one that lets you cast the card) is countered, the card can't be cast. It remains exiled with no time counters on it, and it's no longer suspended.
As the second triggered ability resolves, you must cast the card if able. Timing restrictions based on the card's type are ignored.
If you can't cast the card, perhaps because there are no legal targets available, it remains exiled with no time counters on it, and it's no longer suspended.

If the spell has any mandatory additional costs, you must pay those if able. However, if an additional cost includes a mana payment, you are forced to pay that cost only if there's enough mana in your mana pool at the time you cast the spell. You aren't forced to activate any mana abilities, although you may do so if you wish.
A creature cast using suspend will enter the battlefield with haste. It will have haste until another player gains control of it (or, in some rare cases, gains control of the creature spell itself).

cards.name: Æther Adept
cards.text: When Æther Adept enters the battlefield, return target creature to its owner's hand.
cards.originalText: When Æther Adept enters the battlefield, return target creature to its owner's hand.
cards.flavor: "The universe is my instrument, and the song I play upon it is one you are forbidden to hear."

rulings.text: If there are no other creatures on the battlefield when Æther Adept enters the battlefield, it must target itself.

cards.name: Æther Figment
cards.text:
Kicker {3} (You may pay an additional {3} as you cast this spell.)
Æther Figment can't be blocked.
If Æther Figment was kicked, it enters the battlefield with two +1/+1 counters on it.
cards.originalText:
Kicker {3} (You may pay an additional {3} as you cast this spell.)
Æther Figment can't be blocked.
If Æther Figment was kicked, it enters the battlefield with two +1/+1 counters on it.

cards.name: Agoraphobia
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets -5/-0.
{2}{U}: Return Agoraphobia to its owner's hand.
cards.originalText:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets -5/-0.
{2}{U}: Return Agoraphobia to its owner's hand.
cards.flavor: "Everyone in this city is choosing sides. I choose inside."

rulings.text: Only Agoraphobia's controller can activate its last ability, no matter who controls the creature Agoraphobia's attached to.
Agoraphobia's last ability can be activated only while it's on the battlefield.

Players don't have priority to cast spells and activate abilities between combat damage being assigned and being dealt. This means that if you want to return Agoraphobia to its owner's hand before combat damage is dealt, you must do so before combat damage is assigned (and the creature will no longer get -5/-0).

cards.name: Archaeomancer
cards.text: When Archaeomancer enters the battlefield, return target instant or sorcery card from your graveyard to your hand.
cards.originalText: When Archaeomancer enters the battlefield, return target instant or sorcery card from your graveyard to your hand.
cards.flavor: "Words of power never disappear. They sleep, awaiting those with the will to rouse them."

rulings.text: If an instant or sorcery spell puts Archaeomancer onto the battlefield, you can return that card to your hand.

cards.name: Body Double
cards.text: You may have Body Double enter the battlefield as a copy of any creature card in a graveyard.
cards.originalText: You may have Body Double enter the battlefield as a copy of any creature card in a graveyard.
cards.flavor: "I am who I pretend to be."

rulings.text: Treat Body Double as though it were the chosen card entering the battlefield. Any "As this card enters the battlefield," "This card enters the battlefield with," and "When this card enters the battlefield" abilities of the chosen card will work.

You don't have to choose a card to copy. If you don't, Body Double enters the battlefield as a 0/0 creature and is probably put into your graveyard immediately, unless something is increasing its toughness to keep it alive.

If Body Double copies a Vesuvan Shapeshifter which then copies another creature and then is somehow turned face down, the Body Double is now a face-down Vesuvan Shapeshifter and may be turned face up via its Morph ability.

cards.name: Chronomaton
cards.text: {1}, {T}: Put a +1/+1 counter on Chronomaton.
cards.originalText: {1}, {T}: Put a +1/+1 counter on Chronomaton.
cards.flavor: On the third night, the villagers destroyed their clocks. The sounds of whirring gears and chiming metal held only dread for them.

cards.name: Claustrophobia
cards.text:
Enchant creature
When Claustrophobia enters the battlefield, tap enchanted creature.
Enchanted creature doesn't untap during its controller's untap step.
cards.originalText:
Enchant creature
When Claustrophobia enters the battlefield, tap enchanted creature.
Enchanted creature doesn't untap during its controller's untap step.
cards.flavor: Six feet of earth muffled his cries.

rulings.text: Claustrophobia can target and enchant a tapped or untapped creature.
The enchanted creature can still be untapped in other ways. Claustrophobia will remain attached, and the creature will continue to not untap during its controller’s untap step.

cards.name: Consume Strength
cards.text: Target creature gets +2/+2 until end of turn. Another target creature gets -2/-2 until end of turn.
cards.originalText: Target creature gets +2/+2 until end of turn. Another target creature gets -2/-2 until end of turn.
cards.flavor:
"You are correct. This is going to hurt."
—Vraska

cards.name: Control Magic
cards.text:
Enchant creature
You control enchanted creature.
cards.originalText:
Enchant creature
You control enchanted creature.
cards.flavor:
"Do as I think, not as I do."
—Jace Beleren

rulings.text: You take control of a creature, but Auras enchanting and Equipment attached to the creature do not change controller.

cards.name: Corpse Traders
cards.text: {2}{B}, Sacrifice a creature: Target opponent reveals his or her hand. You choose a card from it. That player discards that card. Activate this ability only any time you could cast a sorcery.
cards.originalText: {2}{B}, Sacrifice a creature: Target opponent reveals his or her hand. You choose a card from it. That player discards that card. Activate this ability only any time you could cast a sorcery.
cards.flavor: Those without breath can't complain.

rulings.text: You can sacrifice Corpse Traders to pay the cost of its ability.

If you cast this as normal during your main phase, it will enter the battlefield and you'll receive priority. If no abilities trigger because of this, you can activate its ability immediately, before any other player has a chance to remove it from the battlefield.

cards.name: Crosstown Courier
cards.text: Whenever Crosstown Courier deals combat damage to a player, that player puts that many cards from the top of his or her library into his or her graveyard.
cards.originalText: Whenever Crosstown Courier deals combat damage to a player, that player puts that many cards from the top of his or her library into his or her graveyard.
cards.flavor: Information travels quickly through Ravnica's network of messengers and thought agents.

cards.name: Death-Hood Cobra
cards.text:
{1}{G}: Death-Hood Cobra gains reach until end of turn. (It can block creatures with flying.)
{1}{G}: Death-Hood Cobra gains deathtouch until end of turn. (Any amount of damage it deals to a creature is enough to destroy it.)
cards.originalText:
{1}{G}: Death-Hood Cobra gains reach until end of turn. (It can block creatures with flying.)
{1}{G}: Death-Hood Cobra gains deathtouch until end of turn. (Any amount of damage it deals to a creature is enough to destroy it.)

cards.name: Dread Statuary
cards.text:
{T}: Add {1} to your mana pool.
{4}: Dread Statuary becomes a 4/2 Golem artifact creature until end of turn. It's still a land.
cards.originalText:
{T}: Add {1} to your mana pool.
{4}: Dread Statuary becomes a 4/2 Golem artifact creature until end of turn. It's still a land.
cards.flavor: The last reliable landmark in Tazeem just walked away.

rulings.text: A land that becomes a creature may be affected by "summoning sickness." You can't attack with it or use any of its {T} abilities (including its mana abilities) unless it began your most recent turn on the battlefield under your control. Note that summoning sickness cares about when that permanent came under your control, not when it became a creature.
The enchanted permanent will be both a land and a creature and can be affected by anything that affects either a land or a creature.

When a land becomes a creature, that doesn't count as having a creature enter the battlefield. The permanent was already on the battlefield; it only changed its types. Abilities that trigger whenever a creature enters the battlefield won't trigger.

An attacking or blocking creature that stops being a creature is removed from combat. This can happen if a Zendikon enchanting an attacking or blocking creature leaves the battlefield, for example. The permanent that was removed from combat neither deals nor is dealt combat damage. Any attacking creature that the land creature was blocking remains blocked, however.

An ability that turns a land into a creature also sets that creature's power and toughness. If the land was already a creature (due to a Zendikon already enchanting it or its animation ability resolving earlier in the turn, for example), this will overwrite the previous effect that set its power and toughness. Effects that modified its power or toughness, such as the effects of Disfigure or Glorious Anthem, will continue to apply, no matter when they started to take effect. The same is true for counters that change its power or toughness (such as +1/+1 counters) and effects that switch its power and toughness.
If a Zendikon and the land it's enchanting are destroyed at the same time (due to Akroma's Vengeance, for example), the Zendikon's last ability will still trigger.
If a Zendikon's last ability triggers, but the land card it refers to leaves the graveyard before it resolves, it will resolve but do nothing.

cards.name: Dream Stalker
cards.text: When Dream Stalker enters the battlefield, return a permanent you control to its owner's hand.
cards.originalText: When Dream Stalker enters the battlefield, return a permanent you control to its owner's hand.
cards.flavor: What happens when it is the dream that wakes and the sleeper that fades into memory?

cards.name: Drooling Groodion
cards.text: {2}{B}{G}, Sacrifice a creature: Target creature gets +2/+2 until end of turn. Another target creature gets -2/-2 until end of turn.
cards.originalText: {2}{B}{G}, Sacrifice a creature: Target creature gets +2/+2 until end of turn. Another target creature gets -2/-2 until end of turn.
cards.flavor:
"The Golgari expand, yes, but I refuse to call their tainted creations ‘growth.'"
—Niszka, Selesnya evangel

foreignNames.name: よだれ垂らしのグルーディオン

cards.text:

Suspend 4—{1}{U} (Rather than cast this card from your hand, you may pay {1}{U} and exile it with four time counters on it. At the beginning of your upkeep, remove a time counter. When the last is removed, cast it without paying its mana cost. It has haste.)
cards.originalText:
Flying
Suspend 4—{1}{U} (Rather than cast this card from your hand, you may pay {1}{U} and exile it with four time counters on it. At the beginning of your upkeep, remove a time counter. When the last is removed, cast it without paying its mana cost. It has haste.)

rulings.text: You can exile a card in your hand using suspend any time you could cast that card. Consider its card type, any effect that affects when you could cast it (such as flash) and any other effects that could stop you from casting it (such as Meddling Mage's effect) to determine if and when you can do this. Whether or not you could actually complete all steps in casting the card is irrelevant. For example, you can exile a card with suspend that has no mana cost or requires a target even if no legal targets are available at that time.
Exiling a card with suspend isn't casting that card. This action doesn't use the stack and can't be responded to.
If the spell requires any targets, those targets are chosen when the spell is finally cast, not when it's exiled.
If the first triggered ability of suspend (the one that removes time counters) is countered, no time counter is removed. The ability will trigger again during the card's owner's next upkeep.
When the last time counter is removed, the second triggered ability of suspend will trigger. It doesn't matter why the last time counter was removed or what effect removed it.
If the second triggered ability of suspend (the one that lets you cast the card) is countered, the card can't be cast. It remains exiled with no time counters on it, and it's no longer suspended.
As the second triggered ability resolves, you must cast the card if able. Timing restrictions based on the card's type are ignored.
If you can't cast the card, perhaps because there are no legal targets available, it remains exiled with no time counters on it, and it's no longer suspended.

If the spell has any mandatory additional costs, you must pay those if able. However, if an additional cost includes a mana payment, you are forced to pay that cost only if there's enough mana in your mana pool at the time you cast the spell. You aren't forced to activate any mana abilities, although you may do so if you wish.
A creature cast using suspend will enter the battlefield with haste. It will have haste until another player gains control of it (or, in some rare cases, gains control of the creature spell itself).

cards.name: Festerhide Boar
cards.text:
Trample
Morbid — Festerhide Boar enters the battlefield with two +1/+1 counters on it if a creature died this turn.
cards.originalText:
Trample
Morbid — Festerhide Boar enters the battlefield with two +1/+1 counters on it if a creature died this turn.
cards.flavor:
"Bury your dead deep. The boars are hungriest while the corpse is still warm."
—Paulin, trapper of Somberwald

cards.name: Future Sight
cards.text:
Play with the top card of your library revealed.
You may play the top card of your library.
cards.originalText:
Play with the top card of your library revealed.
You may play the top card of your library.
cards.flavor:
"Is the inevitable any less miraculous?"
—Veldka, wandering sage

rulings.text: The top card of your library isn't in your hand, so you can't suspend it, cycle it, discard it, or activate any of its activated abilities.
If the top card of your library is a land, you can play it if you could play a land.
If the top card of your library has morph, you can cast that card face down for {3}. However, all players will have seen which card it is before the spell is cast.
As soon as you finish playing the card on top of your library, reveal the next card in your library.
If the top card of your library changes while you're casting a spell or activating an ability, the new top card won't be revealed until you finish casting that spell or activating that ability.

cards.name: Gatecreeper Vine
cards.text:
Defender
When Gatecreeper Vine enters the battlefield, you may search your library for a basic land card or a Gate card, reveal it, put it into your hand, then shuffle your library.
cards.originalText:
Defender
When Gatecreeper Vine enters the battlefield, you may search your library for a basic land card or a Gate card, reveal it, put it into your hand, then shuffle your library.
cards.flavor: Every inch of Ravnica is home to something.

cards.name: Golgari Guildgate
cards.text:
Golgari Guildgate enters the battlefield tapped.
{T}: Add {B} or {G} to your mana pool.
cards.originalText:
Golgari Guildgate enters the battlefield tapped.
{T}: Add {B} or {G} to your mana pool.
cards.flavor: Enter those who are starving and sick. You are welcome among the Swarm when the rest of Ravnica rejects you.

rulings.text: The subtype Gate has no special rules significance, but other spells and abilities may refer to it.
Gate is not a basic land type.

cards.name: Griptide
cards.text: Put target creature on top of its owner's library.
cards.originalText: Put target creature on top of its owner's library.
cards.flavor:
"Beware the seagrafs just off the shore. These waters are filled with hungry geists looking for an easy meal."
—Captain Eberhart

cards.name: Grisly Spectacle
cards.text: Destroy target nonartifact creature. Its controller puts a number of cards equal to that creature's power from the top of his or her library into his or her graveyard.
cards.originalText: Destroy target nonartifact creature. Its controller puts a number of cards equal to that creature's power from the top of his or her library into his or her graveyard.
cards.flavor:
"Watch people flock to a murder scene. Then tell me we're not all a little sick in the head."
—Juri, proprietor of the Juri Revue

rulings.text: Use the creature's power the last time it was on the battlefield to determine how many cards its controller puts into his or her graveyard.

If the creature is an illegal target when Grisly Spectacle tries to resolve, it will be countered and none of its effects will happen. The creature's controller won't put any cards into his or her graveyard.

cards.name: Halimar Depths
cards.text:
Halimar Depths enters the battlefield tapped.
When Halimar Depths enters the battlefield, look at the top three cards of your library, then put them back in any order.
{T}: Add {U} to your mana pool.
cards.originalText:
Halimar Depths enters the battlefield tapped.
When Halimar Depths enters the battlefield, look at the top three cards of your library, then put them back in any order.
{T}: Add {U} to your mana pool.

cards.name: Highway Robber
cards.text: When Highway Robber enters the battlefield, target opponent loses 2 life and you gain 2 life.
cards.originalText: When Highway Robber enters the battlefield, target opponent loses 2 life and you gain 2 life.
cards.flavor: "Tonight, madam, it's your money and your life."

cards.name: Hypnotic Cloud
cards.text:
Kicker {4} (You may pay an additional {4} as you cast this spell.)
Target player discards a card. If Hypnotic Cloud was kicked, that player discards three cards instead.
cards.originalText:
Kicker {4} (You may pay an additional {4} as you cast this spell.)
Target player discards a card. If Hypnotic Cloud was kicked, that player discards three cards instead.

cards.name: Into the Roil
cards.text:
Kicker {1}{U} (You may pay an additional {1}{U} as you cast this spell.)
Return target nonland permanent to its owner's hand. If Into the Roil was kicked, draw a card.
cards.originalText:
Kicker {1}{U} (You may pay an additional {1}{U} as you cast this spell.)
Return target nonland permanent to its owner's hand. If Into the Roil was kicked, draw a card.
cards.flavor: "Roil tide! Roil tide! Tie yourselves down!"

rulings.text: If the targeted permanent is an illegal target by the time Into the Roil resolves, the entire spell is countered. You don't draw a card.

cards.name: Jace's Ingenuity
cards.text: Draw three cards.
cards.originalText: Draw three cards.
cards.flavor: "Brute force can sometimes kick down a locked door, but knowledge is a skeleton key."

cards.name: Jace's Mindseeker
cards.text:
Flying
When Jace's Mindseeker enters the battlefield, target opponent puts the top five cards of his or her library into his or her graveyard. You may cast an instant or sorcery card from among them without paying its mana cost.
cards.originalText:
Flying
When Jace's Mindseeker enters the battlefield, target opponent puts the top five cards of his or her library into his or her graveyard. You may cast an instant or sorcery card from among them without paying its mana cost.

cards.name: Jace's Phantasm
cards.text:
Flying
Jace's Phantasm gets +4/+4 as long as an opponent has ten or more cards in his or her graveyard.
cards.originalText:
Flying
Jace's Phantasm gets +4/+4 as long as an opponent has ten or more cards in his or her graveyard.
cards.flavor: In the abstract memories of the Iquati, Jace found interesting ideas to improve upon.

rulings.text: The last ability constantly monitors each opponent's graveyard to see if the bonus applies. If the stated condition becomes no longer true, the bonus immediately stops applying.

In a multiplayer game, a single opponent must have ten or more cards in his or her graveyard for the bonus to apply, although this opponent may change over the course of the game. You don't have to pick a single opponent; the ability will monitor each opponent's graveyard.

cards.name: Jace, Architect of Thought
cards.text:
+1: Until your next turn, whenever a creature an opponent controls attacks, it gets -1/-0 until end of turn.
−2: Reveal the top three cards of your library. An opponent separates those cards into two piles. Put one pile into your hand and the other on the bottom of your library in any order.
−8: For each player, search that player's library for a nonland card and exile it, then that player shuffles his or her library. You may cast those cards without paying their mana costs.
cards.originalText:
+1: Until your next turn, whenever a creature an opponent controls attacks, it gets -1/-0 until end of turn.
-2: Reveal the top three cards of your library. An opponent separates those cards into two piles. Put one pile into your hand and the other on the bottom of your library in any order.
-8: For each player, search that player's library for a nonland card and exile it, then that player shuffles his or her library. You may cast those cards without paying their mana costs.

rulings.text: Jace's first ability creates a delayed triggered ability that triggers whenever a creature an opponent controls attacks. It doesn't matter which player or planeswalker that creature is attacking.

You pick one of your opponents when Jace's second ability resolves. The ability doesn't target that opponent. All players may see the revealed cards and offer opinions. You (not your opponent) choose which pile is put into your hand and which pile is put on the bottom of your library.
Piles can be empty. If one of the piles is empty, you choose to put all the revealed cards in your hand or on the bottom of your library.
When resolving Jace's third ability, you search each player's library (including yours) and exile the nonland cards before casting any of them.

For each library, the search is complete only when you explicitly say it is. For example, you can look through one player's library, set that library down, look at another player's library, choose a nonland card in the first library, then choose a nonland card in the second library. Don't reveal any cards from those libraries to any other player until you exile them.
You cast the cards by putting them on the stack one at a time, choosing modes, targets, and so on. The last card you cast will be the first one to resolve.
When casting a card this way, ignore timing restrictions based on the card's type. Other timing restrictions, such as “Cast [this card] only during combat,” must be followed.
If you can't cast a card, perhaps because there are no legal targets available, or if you choose not to cast one, it will remain exiled. Jace's ability won't allow you to cast it later.

If you cast a card “without paying its mana cost,” you can't pay alternative costs such as overload costs. You can pay additional costs such as kicker costs. If the card has mandatory additional costs, you must pay those.
If a card has {X} in its mana cost, you must choose 0 as its value.
Planeswalkers are permanents. You can cast one at the time you could cast a sorcery. When your planeswalker spell resolves, it enters the battlefield under your control.
Planeswalkers are not creatures. Spells and abilities that affect creatures won’t affect them.

Planeswalkers have loyalty. A planeswalker enters the battlefield with a number of loyalty counters on it equal to the number printed in its lower right corner. Activating one of its abilities may cause it to gain or lose loyalty counters. Damage dealt to a planeswalker causes that many loyalty counters to be removed from it. If it has no loyalty counters on it, it’s put into its owner’s graveyard as a state-based action.

Planeswalkers each have a number of activated abilities called “loyalty abilities.” You can activate a loyalty ability of a planeswalker you control only at the time you could cast a sorcery and only if you haven’t activated one of that planeswalker’s loyalty abilities yet that turn.

The cost to activate a planeswalker’s loyalty ability is represented by a symbol with a number inside. Up-arrows contain positive numbers, such as “+1”; this means “Put one loyalty counter on this planeswalker.” Down-arrows contain negative numbers, such as “-7”; this means “Remove seven loyalty counters from this planeswalker.” A symbol with a “0” means “Put zero loyalty counters on this planeswalker.”
You can’t activate a planeswalker’s ability with a negative loyalty cost unless the planeswalker has at least that many loyalty counters on it.

Planeswalkers can’t attack (unless an effect turns the planeswalker into a creature). However, they can be attacked. Each of your attacking creatures can attack your opponent or a planeswalker that player controls. You say which as you declare attackers.
If your planeswalkers are being attacked, you can block the attackers as normal.
If a creature that’s attacking a planeswalker isn’t blocked, it’ll deal its combat damage to that planeswalker. Damage dealt to a planeswalker causes that many loyalty counters to be removed from it.

If a source you control would deal noncombat damage to an opponent, you may have that source deal that damage to a planeswalker that opponent controls instead. For example, although you can’t target a planeswalker with Shock, you can target your opponent with Shock, and then as Shock resolves, choose to have Shock deal its 2 damage to one of your opponent’s planeswalkers. (You can’t split up that damage between different players and/or planeswalkers.) If you have Shock deal its damage to a planeswalker, two loyalty counters are removed from it.
If a player controls two or more planeswalkers that share a planeswalker type, that player chooses one of them and the rest are put into their owners’ graveyards as a state-based action.

foreignNames.name: 思考を築く者、ジェイス

cards.name: Krovikan Mist
cards.text:
Flying
Krovikan Mist's power and toughness are each equal to the number of Illusions on the battlefield.
cards.originalText:
Flying
Krovikan Mist's power and toughness are each equal to the number of Illusions on the battlefield.
cards.flavor:
"It's as strong as you believe it is, and it's very convincing."
—Jace Beleren

cards.name: Last Kiss
cards.text: Last Kiss deals 2 damage to target creature and you gain 2 life.
cards.originalText: Last Kiss deals 2 damage to target creature and you gain 2 life.
cards.flavor:
"Romanticize it, glamorize it, call it what you will. To me, it will always be carnal, bloody murder."
—Ayli, Kamsa cleric

rulings.text: You gain 2 life even if the damage is prevented.
If the targeted creature is an illegal target by the time Last Kiss resolves, the spell is countered. You won't gain life.

cards.name: Leyline Phantom
cards.text: When Leyline Phantom deals combat damage, return it to its owner's hand. (Return it only if it survived combat.)
cards.originalText: When Leyline Phantom deals combat damage, return it to its owner's hand. (Return it only if it survived combat.)
cards.flavor:
"Is the maze itself a phantom? Or is one as real as the other? Perhaps I am as mad as the dragon."
—Jace Beleren, journal

cards.name: Marsh Casualties
cards.text:
Kicker {3} (You may pay an additional {3} as you cast this spell.)
Creatures target player controls get -1/-1 until end of turn. If Marsh Casualties was kicked, those creatures get -2/-2 until end of turn instead.
cards.originalText:
Kicker {3} (You may pay an additional {3} as you cast this spell.)
Creatures target player controls get -1/-1 until end of turn. If Marsh Casualties was kicked, those creatures get -2/-2 until end of turn instead.

cards.name: Memory Lapse
cards.text: Counter target spell. If that spell is countered this way, put it on top of its owner's library instead of into that player's graveyard.
cards.originalText: Counter target spell. If that spell is countered this way, put it on top of its owner's library instead of into that player's graveyard.
cards.flavor:
"To sculpt a mind is to see every memory and thought as an individual piece that can be rearranged—or removed."
—Jace Beleren

rulings.text: The card does not go to the graveyard before being put on the library.

This card has a self replacement. This means that it replaces going to the graveyard before any other effect can replace that event. If Flashback is applied, however, Flashback will change the destination.
If the spell is not countered (because the spell it targets can't be countered), then it does not go to its owner's library.

cards.name: Merfolk Wayfinder
cards.text:

cards.originalText:
Flying
When Merfolk Wayfinder enters the battlefield, reveal the top three cards of your library. Put all Island cards revealed this way into your hand and the rest on the bottom of your library in any order.

rulings.text: If there are three or fewer cards in your library, you'll reveal all of them.

cards.name: Mold Shambler

cards.originalText:
Kicker {1}{G} (You may pay an additional {1}{G} as you cast this spell.)
When Mold Shambler enters the battlefield, if it was kicked, destroy target noncreature permanent.

cards.originalText:
First strike
When Nekrataal enters the battlefield, destroy target nonartifact, nonblack creature. That creature can't be regenerated.

—Vraska

rulings.text: Nothing happens if there are no non-artifact, non-black creatures on the battlefield when it enters the battlefield.

cards.name: Night's Whisper
cards.text: You draw two cards and you lose 2 life.
cards.originalText: You draw two cards and you lose 2 life.
cards.flavor:

cards.name: Ohran Viper
cards.text:
Whenever Ohran Viper deals combat damage to a creature, destroy that creature at end of combat.
Whenever Ohran Viper deals combat damage to a player, you may draw a card.
cards.originalText:
Whenever Ohran Viper deals combat damage to a creature, destroy that creature at end of combat.
Whenever Ohran Viper deals combat damage to a player, you may draw a card.
cards.flavor: The ohran viper is not cold-blooded. Its veins course with the same antigelid venom used to kill its prey.

Reach (This creature can block creatures with flying.)

cards.originalText:
Kicker {2}{G} (You may pay an additional {2}{G} as you cast this spell.)
Reach (This creature can block creatures with flying.)

cards.name: Phantasmal Bear

cards.originalText: When Phantasmal Bear becomes the target of a spell or ability, sacrifice it.

—Pol Jamaar, illusionist

Flying
When Phantasmal Dragon becomes the target of a spell or ability, sacrifice it.
cards.originalText:

When Phantasmal Dragon becomes the target of a spell or ability, sacrifice it.

Counter target spell if its converted mana cost is 2 or less. If Prohibit was kicked, counter that spell if its converted mana cost is 4 or less instead.
cards.originalText:
Kicker {2} (You may pay an additional {2} as you cast this spell.)
Counter target spell if its converted mana cost is 2 or less. If Prohibit was kicked, counter that spell if its converted mana cost is 4 or less instead.

cards.name: Pulse Tracker
cards.text: Whenever Pulse Tracker attacks, each opponent loses 1 life.
cards.originalText: Whenever Pulse Tracker attacks, each opponent loses 1 life.
cards.flavor:
"You can't think your way out of this, Jace. Thought implies life, and life requires a pulse—music to a hunter's ears."
—Vraska

cards.name: Putrid Leech
cards.text: Pay 2 life: Putrid Leech gets +2/+2 until end of turn. Activate this ability only once each turn.
cards.originalText: Pay 2 life: Putrid Leech gets +2/+2 until end of turn. Activate this ability only once each turn.
cards.flavor:
"The Golgari would say that life comes from death and death comes from life. But sometimes, death comes from the dead."
—Vraska

cards.name: Ray of Command
cards.text: Untap target creature an opponent controls and gain control of it until end of turn. That creature gains haste until end of turn. When you lose control of the creature, tap it.
cards.originalText: Untap target creature an opponent controls and gain control of it until end of turn. That creature gains haste until end of turn. When you lose control of the creature, tap it.
cards.flavor: "Heel."

rulings.text: You may target an untapped creature with Ray of Command.

The creature returns to the opponent when the "until end of turn" effect wears off during the cleanup step. It taps during the Cleanup step (if it is not already tapped), so any abilities triggered off it tapping happen at that time.
You tap the creature when you lose control of it for any reason -- because Ray of Command's effect ends, or because a spell or ability causes another player to gain control of it.

cards.name: Reaper of the Wilds
cards.text:
Whenever another creature dies, scry 1. (Look at the top card of your library. You may put that card on the bottom of your library.)
{B}: Reaper of the Wilds gains deathtouch until end of turn.
{1}{G}: Reaper of the Wilds gains hexproof until end of turn.
cards.originalText:
Whenever another creature dies, scry 1. (Look at the top card of your library. You may put that card on the bottom of your library.)
{B}: Reaper of the Wilds gains deathtouch until end of turn.
{1}{G}: Reaper of the Wilds gains hexproof until end of turn.

rulings.text: Reaper of the Wilds’s first ability triggers separately for each creature. For example, if five creatures die at the same time, you’ll scry 1 five times. You won’t scry 5.
If Reaper of the Wilds dies at the same time as another creature, its ability will trigger for that other creature.

When you scry, you may put all the cards you look at back on top of your library, you may put all of those cards on the bottom of your library, or you may put some of those cards on top and the rest of them on the bottom.
You choose how to order cards returned to your library after scrying no matter where you put them.
You perform the actions stated on a card in sequence. For some spells and abilities, that means you’ll scry last. For others, that means you’ll scry and then perform other actions.

Scry appears on some spells and abilities with one or more targets. If all of the spell or ability’s targets are illegal when it tries to resolve, it will be countered and none of its effects will happen. You won’t scry.

cards.name: Remand
cards.text:
Counter target spell. If that spell is countered this way, put it into its owner's hand instead of into that player's graveyard.
Draw a card.
cards.originalText:
Counter target spell. If that spell is countered this way, put it into its owner's hand instead of into that player's graveyard.
Draw a card.
cards.flavor: For the Azorius, the law can be a physical shield against chaos and anarchy.

rulings.text: The countered spell goes to its owner's hand from the stack. It never hits the graveyard.
If you Remand a card with Flashback, the card will still be exiled.

cards.name: Riftwing Cloudskate
cards.text:
Flying
When Riftwing Cloudskate enters the battlefield, return target permanent to its owner's hand.
Suspend 3—{1}{U} (Rather than cast this card from your hand, you may pay {1}{U} and exile it with three time counters on it. At the beginning of your upkeep, remove a time counter. When the last is removed, cast it without paying its mana cost. It has haste.)
cards.originalText:
Flying
When Riftwing Cloudskate enters the battlefield, return target permanent to its owner's hand.
Suspend 3—{1}{U} (Rather than cast this card from your hand, you may pay {1}{U} and exile it with three time counters on it. At the beginning of your upkeep, remove a time counter. When the last is removed, cast it without paying its mana cost. It has haste.)

rulings.text: You can exile a card in your hand using suspend any time you could cast that card. Consider its card type, any effect that affects when you could cast it (such as flash) and any other effects that could stop you from casting it (such as Meddling Mage's effect) to determine if and when you can do this. Whether or not you could actually complete all steps in casting the card is irrelevant. For example, you can exile a card with suspend that has no mana cost or requires a target even if no legal targets are available at that time.
Exiling a card with suspend isn't casting that card. This action doesn't use the stack and can't be responded to.
If the spell requires any targets, those targets are chosen when the spell is finally cast, not when it's exiled.
If the first triggered ability of suspend (the one that removes time counters) is countered, no time counter is removed. The ability will trigger again during the card's owner's next upkeep.
When the last time counter is removed, the second triggered ability of suspend will trigger. It doesn't matter why the last time counter was removed or what effect removed it.
If the second triggered ability of suspend (the one that lets you cast the card) is countered, the card can't be cast. It remains exiled with no time counters on it, and it's no longer suspended.
As the second triggered ability resolves, you must cast the card if able. Timing restrictions based on the card's type are ignored.
If you can't cast the card, perhaps because there are no legal targets available, it remains exiled with no time counters on it, and it's no longer suspended.

If the spell has any mandatory additional costs, you must pay those if able. However, if an additional cost includes a mana payment, you are forced to pay that cost only if there's enough mana in your mana pool at the time you cast the spell. You aren't forced to activate any mana abilities, although you may do so if you wish.
A creature cast using suspend will enter the battlefield with haste. It will have haste until another player gains control of it (or, in some rare cases, gains control of the creature spell itself).

foreignNames.name: 裂け目翼の雲間を泳ぐもの

cards.name: River Boa

rulings.text: Activating the second ability of Rogue's Passage after a creature has become blocked won't cause it to become unblocked.

cards.originalText: When Sadistic Augermage dies, each player puts a card from his or her hand on top of his or her library.

cards.name: Sea Gate Oracle

cards.originalText: When Sea Gate Oracle enters the battlefield, look at the top two cards of your library. Put one of them into your hand and the other on the bottom of your library.
cards.flavor: "The secret entrance should be near."

rulings.text: If there's only one card in your library as this ability resolves, you'll put it into your hand.

cards.name: Shadow Alley Denizen
cards.text: Whenever another black creature enters the battlefield under your control, target creature gains intimidate until end of turn. (It can't be blocked except by artifact creatures and/or creatures that share a color with it.)
cards.originalText: Whenever another black creature enters the battlefield under your control, target creature gains intimidate until end of turn. (It can't be blocked except by artifact creatures and/or creatures that share a color with it.)

rulings.text: The black creature that entered the battlefield can be chosen as the target of Shadow Alley Denizen's ability, but it won't be able to attack that turn unless it also has haste.
Shadow Alley Denizen can be chosen as the target of its own ability.

cards.name: Slate Street Ruffian
cards.text: Whenever Slate Street Ruffian becomes blocked, defending player discards a card.
cards.originalText: Whenever Slate Street Ruffian becomes blocked, defending player discards a card.
cards.flavor:
"Merciless to the point of psychosis. Let's give him a job."
—Zelinas, Orzhov recruiter

cards.name: Spawnwrithe
cards.text:
Trample
Whenever Spawnwrithe deals combat damage to a player, put a token that's a copy of Spawnwrithe onto the battlefield.
cards.originalText:
Trample
Whenever Spawnwrithe deals combat damage to a player, put a token that's a copy of Spawnwrithe onto the battlefield.
cards.flavor: Its victims feel only an itchy, wriggling feeling just under their skin. By then, it's far too late.

rulings.text: As the token is created, it checks the printed values of the Spawnwrithe it's copying -- or, if the Spawnwrithe whose ability triggered was itself a token, the original characteristics of that token as stated by the effect that put it onto the battlefield -- as well as any copy effects that have been applied to it. It won't copy counters on the Spawnwrithe, nor will it copy other effects that have changed Spawnwrithe's power, toughness, types, color, or so on. Normally, this means the token will simply be a Spawnwrithe. But if any copy effects have affected that Spawnwrithe, they're taken into account.

If Spawnwrithe's ability triggers, then Spawnwrithe becomes a copy of another creature before its ability resolves (due to Mirrorweave, perhaps), the token will be a copy of whatever creature the Spawnwrithe is currently a copy of. At the end of the turn, Spawnwrithe will revert back to what it was, but the token will stay as it is.

If a copy effect such as Mirrorweave causes some other creature to become a copy of Spawnwrithe, then that creature deals combat damage to a player, the token that's put onto the battlefield is simply a copy of Spawnwrithe.
A token created by a Cemetery Puca that's copying a Spawnwrithe will be a Spawnwrithe with the Cemetery Puca ability.

cards.name: Spelltwine
cards.text: Exile target instant or sorcery card from your graveyard and target instant or sorcery card from an opponent's graveyard. Copy those cards. Cast the copies if able without paying their mana costs. Exile Spelltwine.
cards.originalText: Exile target instant or sorcery card from your graveyard and target instant or sorcery card from an opponent's graveyard. Copy those cards. Cast the copies if able without paying their mana costs. Exile Spelltwine.

rulings.text: Spelltwine has two targets: the instant or sorcery card in your graveyard and the one in an opponent's graveyard. You can't cast Spelltwine unless you can choose both legal targets.
If one of Spelltwine's targets is illegal when Spelltwine tries to resolve, you'll still exile and copy the remaining legal target.
The copies are created in exile and cast from exile. The cards remain exiled.
You can cast the copies in either order.
The copy you cast first will already be on the stack when you cast the other copy. If that spell targets a spell, you may choose the first copy as a legal target.

If you cast a card "without paying its mana cost," you can't pay any alternative costs. You can pay additional costs such as kicker costs. If the card has mandatory additional costs, you must pay those.
If the card has X in its mana cost, you must choose 0 as its value.

cards.name: Stab Wound
cards.text:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets -2/-2.
At the beginning of the upkeep of enchanted creature's controller, that player loses 2 life.
cards.originalText:
Enchant creature
Enchanted creature gets -2/-2.
At the beginning of the upkeep of enchanted creature's controller, that player loses 2 life.

cards.name: Stealer of Secrets
cards.text: Whenever Stealer of Secrets deals combat damage to a player, draw a card.
cards.originalText: Whenever Stealer of Secrets deals combat damage to a player, draw a card.
cards.flavor: The Dimir would hire her, if only they knew where she lived. The Azorius would condemn her, if only they knew her name.

cards.name: Stonefare Crocodile
cards.text: {2}{B}: Stonefare Crocodile gains lifelink until end of turn. (Damage dealt by this creature also causes you to gain that much life.)
cards.originalText: {2}{B}: Stonefare Crocodile gains lifelink until end of turn. (Damage dealt by this creature also causes you to gain that much life.)

rulings.text: Multiple instances of lifelink are redundant. Activating Stonefare Crocodile's ability more than once during a single turn won't cause you to gain more life.

foreignNames.name: 石載りのクロコダイル

cards.text: Counter target creature spell. Put a 2/2 blue Illusion creature token onto the battlefield.
cards.originalText: Counter target creature spell. Put a 2/2 blue Illusion creature token onto the battlefield.
cards.flavor:
"I don't need to have the perfect plan. My foe just has to have an imperfect one."
—Jace Beleren

rulings.text: If the targeted spell is an illegal target by the time Summoner's Bane resolves, the entire spell is countered. You won't get a creature token.
You get the token creature, not the controller of the creature spell.

cards.name: Tavern Swindler
cards.text: {T}, Pay 3 life: Flip a coin. If you win the flip, you gain 6 life.
cards.originalText: {T}, Pay 3 life: Flip a coin. If you win the flip, you gain 6 life.
cards.flavor: Rakdos cultists are her best customers. They never flinch at pain and are seldom good at math.

rulings.text: You can't activate the ability if your life total is less than 3.
You can activate the ability if your life total is 3, but it's probably a bad idea. You'll lose the game before the ability resolves.

cards.name: Thought Scour
cards.text:
Target player puts the top two cards of his or her library into his or her graveyard.
Draw a card.
cards.originalText:
Target player puts the top two cards of his or her library into his or her graveyard.
Draw a card.
cards.flavor:
"As you inject the viscus vitae into the brain stem, don't let the spastic moaning bother you. It will soon become music to your ears."
—Stitcher Geralf

rulings.text: If the target player is an illegal target when Thought Scour tries to resolve, it will be countered and none of its effects will happen. You won't draw a card.
Follow the instructions in the order listed on the card: if you target yourself, you'll put the top two cards of your library into your graveyard and then draw a card.

cards.name: Tragic Slip
cards.text:
Target creature gets -1/-1 until end of turn.
Morbid — That creature gets -13/-13 until end of turn instead if a creature died this turn.
cards.originalText:
Target creature gets -1/-1 until end of turn.
Morbid — That creature gets -13/-13 until end of turn instead if a creature died this turn.
cards.flavor: Linger on death's door and risk being invited in.

cards.name: Treasured Find
cards.text: Return target card from your graveyard to your hand. Exile Treasured Find.
cards.originalText: Return target card from your graveyard to your hand. Exile Treasured Find.
cards.flavor: Gorgons crave beautiful things: gems, exquisite amulets, the alabaster corpses of the petrified dead . . .

cards.name: Underworld Connections
cards.text:
Enchant land
Enchanted land has "{T}, Pay 1 life: Draw a card."
cards.originalText:
Enchant land
Enchanted land has "{T}, Pay 1 life: Draw a card."
cards.flavor: If you're looking for it, it's available. The question is how much you're willing to pay.

cards.name: Vinelasher Kudzu
cards.text: Whenever a land enters the battlefield under your control, put a +1/+1 counter on Vinelasher Kudzu.
cards.originalText: Whenever a land enters the battlefield under your control, put a +1/+1 counter on Vinelasher Kudzu.
cards.flavor: It grows to hate you.

cards.name: Vraska the Unseen
cards.text:
+1: Until your next turn, whenever a creature deals combat damage to Vraska the Unseen, destroy that creature.
−3: Destroy target nonland permanent.
−7: Put three 1/1 black Assassin creature tokens onto the battlefield with "Whenever this creature deals combat damage to a player, that player loses the game."
cards.originalText:
+1: Until your next turn, whenever a creature deals combat damage to Vraska the Unseen, destroy that creature.
-3: Destroy target nonland permanent.
-7: Put three 1/1 black Assassin creature tokens onto the battlefield with "Whenever this creature deals combat damage to a player, that player loses the game."

rulings.text: If an effect creates a copy of one of the Assassin creature tokens, the copy will also have the triggered ability.
Each Assassin token's triggered ability will trigger whenever it deals combat damage to any player, including you.
Planeswalkers are permanents. You can cast one at the time you could cast a sorcery. When your planeswalker spell resolves, it enters the battlefield under your control.
Planeswalkers are not creatures. Spells and abilities that affect creatures won’t affect them.

Planeswalkers have loyalty. A planeswalker enters the battlefield with a number of loyalty counters on it equal to the number printed in its lower right corner. Activating one of its abilities may cause it to gain or lose loyalty counters. Damage dealt to a planeswalker causes that many loyalty counters to be removed from it. If it has no loyalty counters on it, it’s put into its owner’s graveyard as a state-based action.

Planeswalkers each have a number of activated abilities called “loyalty abilities.” You can activate a loyalty ability of a planeswalker you control only at the time you could cast a sorcery and only if you haven’t activated one of that planeswalker’s loyalty abilities yet that turn.

The cost to activate a planeswalker’s loyalty ability is represented by a symbol with a number inside. Up-arrows contain positive numbers, such as “+1”; this means “Put one loyalty counter on this planeswalker.” Down-arrows contain negative numbers, such as “-7”; this means “Remove seven loyalty counters from this planeswalker.” A symbol with a “0” means “Put zero loyalty counters on this planeswalker.”
You can’t activate a planeswalker’s ability with a negative loyalty cost unless the planeswalker has at least that many loyalty counters on it.

Planeswalkers can’t attack (unless an effect turns the planeswalker into a creature). However, they can be attacked. Each of your attacking creatures can attack your opponent or a planeswalker that player controls. You say which as you declare attackers.
If your planeswalkers are being attacked, you can block the attackers as normal.
If a creature that’s attacking a planeswalker isn’t blocked, it’ll deal its combat damage to that planeswalker. Damage dealt to a planeswalker causes that many loyalty counters to be removed from it.

If a source you control would deal noncombat damage to an opponent, you may have that source deal that damage to a planeswalker that opponent controls instead. For example, although you can’t target a planeswalker with Shock, you can target your opponent with Shock, and then as Shock resolves, choose to have Shock deal its 2 damage to one of your opponent’s planeswalkers. (You can’t split up that damage between different players and/or planeswalkers.) If you have Shock deal its damage to a planeswalker, two loyalty counters are removed from it.
If a player controls two or more planeswalkers that share a planeswalker type, that player chooses one of them and the rest are put into their owners’ graveyards as a state-based action.

cards.name: Wight of Precinct Six
cards.text: Wight of Precinct Six gets +1/+1 for each creature card in your opponents' graveyards.
cards.originalText: Wight of Precinct Six gets +1/+1 for each creature card in your opponents' graveyards.
cards.flavor: Even the lost and undead need a protector.

rulings.text: Wight of Precinct Six's ability applies only if Wight of Precinct Six is on the battlefield.
